Sure, here's a problem for the student to solve:

A rectangular tank has a length of 3 meters and a width of 2 meters. It is filled with water up to a height of 4 meters. Calculate the pressure of water at the base of the tank. (Density of water = 1000 kg/m³, acceleration due to gravity = 9.8 m/s²)
message_2:
To calculate the pressure of water at the base of the tank, we can use the following formula:

Pressure (P) = Density (ρ) × Acceleration due to gravity (g) × Height (h)

Given the density of water (ρ) = 1000 kg/m³, acceleration due to gravity (g) = 9.8 m/s², and the height of the water in the tank (h) = 4 meters, we can plug these values into the formula:

P = 1000 kg/m³ × 9.8 m/s² × 4 m

P = 1000 × 9.8 × 4

P = 39200 kg m/s² m²

Since 1 Pascal (Pa) is equal to 1 kg m/s² m², the pressure at the base of the tank is:

P = 39200 Pa
